case1: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will swerve and drive through a crossing which will be used by predestrians to cross in the other lane. This will result in the death of 2 OldMan who were crossing in the other lane
case2: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will continue ahead and drive through a crossing which will be used by predestrians to cross in the other lane ahead. This will result in the death of 2 Man who were crossing ahead of the car​
Justification: In this scenario, the self-driving car with sudden brake failure will swerve and drive through a crossing that will be used by pedestrians to cross in the other lane. This decision aligns better with ethical principles of justice and virtue ethics. Justice requires giving people what they are due, and virtuous behavior involves acting in a way that is fair and equal. Swerving to avoid the pedestrians would prioritize their safety over the car's path, which goes against the principle of justice. Additionally, swerving would demonstrate virtuous behavior by prioritizing the well-being of others. On the other hand, continuing ahead and driving through the crossing without checking for pedestrians would be a violation of their right of way and could result in their injury or death. Therefore, swerving to avoid the pedestrians is the more ethical decision.
